datafield.subfield: What is truth? a life problem ...
Cream of human thought; or, Much-in-little library.

I. The function of congnition -- II. The tigers in India -- III. Humanism and truth -- IV. The relation beteen knower and known -- V. The essense of humanism -- VI. A word more about truth -- VII. Professor Pratt on truth -- VIII. The pragmatist account of truth and its misunderstanders -- IX. The meaning of the word truth -- X. The existence of Julius Caesar -- XI. The absolute and the strenuous life -- XII. Professor Hebert on pragmatism -- XIII. Abstractionism and 'Relativismus' -- XIV. Two English critics -- XV. A dialogue.
Master and use copy. Digital master created according to Benchmark for Faithful Digital Reproductions of Monographs and Serials, Version 1. Digital Library Federation, December 2002.

Ch. I. Physics and metaphysics -- Ch. II. Appearance and reality -- Ch. III. The logical theories -- Ch. IV. The absolute -- Ch. V. Pragmatism -- Ch. VI. Utility -- Ch. VII. Illusion -- Ch. VIII. The problem of error -- Ch. IX. Conclusion

A problem of philosophy is completely different from a problem of science. In science we accept our subject-matter as it is presented in unanalysed experience ; in philosophy we examine the first principles and ultimate questions that concern conscious experience itself. The problem of truth is a problem of philosophy. -- Preface.
Sermons of the winter. Series II ;

datafield.subfield: Mode of access: World Wide Web.
What Is truth? -- A world without truth -- Suppressing the truth -- The great divide.

Dr. Sproul focuses on the importance of truth in our thinking, speech and arguments, and adds that the Hebrew concept also includes integrity in living. He notes the widespread aversion to the truth presented in Christian doctrines, and points out God's severe judgment against suppressing the truth.--Ligonier website.
for the Woodbrooke extension committee by Headley Bros.,
Series title also at head of t.p.
Remarks on a late pamphlet entitled Plain truth /

Reviews the discussion between Candidus and Thomas Paine, and proposes that, to secure the rights of the American colonies, "no act of the British Parliament, such only excepted as respect the regulations of our external commerce, shall be valid in America until approved and passed by a Continental Congress."
Nevv-England pesecutors [sic] mauled vvith their own vveapons. :

Giving some account of the bloody laws made at Boston against the Kings subjects that dissented from their way of worship. : Together with a brief account of the imprisonment and tryal of Thomas Maule of Salem, for publishing a book, entituled, Truth held forth and maintained, &c. /
by Tho. Philathes. ; [Six lines of Scripture texts].

The tests of the various kinds of truth:
being a treatise of applied logic,

I. Truths to be assumed: their nature and tests -- II. Discursive or deductive truth: reasoning -- III. Inductive truths: canons of -- IV. The joint dogmatic and deductive method: the joint inductive and deductive, hypotheses and verification, chance, induction cannot give absolute truth, we know in part -- V. Testimony: is it sufficient to prove the supernatural?.
